posts.name: Nathan Hickman
posts.cooked: My team (2129) has had some issues all season with the cooling of our NEOs. I saw on here that many people have said that they are supposed to cool through the faceplate. this seems probable looking at the inside of a NEO that we smoked but it does not say anywhere on REVs website that the motors are supposed to cool through the faceplate. If you could give us some clarification it would be greatly appreciated.

posts.name: Brendan Simons, 5406
posts.cooked: What current limit are you using?  Keeping them under ~50A should not result in any over heating per Rev‚Äôs testing: NEO Brushless Motor - Locked-rotor Testing

posts.name: Jon Stratis
posts.cooked:
There‚Äôs no active cooling on the NEO‚Äôs (unlike, for example, a 775, which integrates a fan to move air through to cool while running).  Instead, it relies of passive cooling - it gets hot, and the air around it will slowly cool it back down.

The question becomes, how does it get hot - in this case, the primary heat transfer is through the front face, as it‚Äôs connected to the coils inside, while the back case is more of a shroud to cover the moving components, with no direct contact with anything except the front face.

In terms of smoking them‚Ä¶ what‚Äôs the use case?  What gear ratio, what load, how long is it running, is it being stalled?  Instead of looking for a cooling solution of some sort, it might be better to examine your mechanism to see what you can do to prevent the heat generation in the first place!

posts.name: Nathan Hickman
posts.cooked: A team we are with at our practice field told us to do that and we are about to test that but we already dropped like 500$ on NEOs this season and we are not really willing to buy anymore so we just want to make sure that we don kill anymore.

posts.name: Nathan Hickman
posts.cooked: We are using them on our climber and the main thing that seems to kill them is overcurrent and winding the rope in the wrong directing stalling the motor. and they got hot enough at some points to literally burn my hand.

posts.name: Brendan Simons, 5406
posts.cooked:
NaHick2129:

we just want to make sure that we don kill anymore.

A current limit should prevent you from killing any more Neos and it‚Äôs an easy software fix.   That said, it will reduce the torque so if it‚Äôs connected to heavy mechanism (say, a climber), you may need to change your gear ratio so that it will continue to operate with less torque.

posts.name: Nathan Hickman
posts.cooked: yea its already at a very high ratio and its also paired with another NEO so we have 4 NEOs for our two telescoping arms.

posts.name: Jon Stratis
posts.cooked:
We burned 2 NEO‚Äôs on our climber due to some programming/testing accidents in a similar way, accidentally stalling them for extended periods without anyone realizing.  As a result, we ended up writing some anti-stall code specifically for those climber motors.  Basically, we use the encoder in the NEO to ask ‚Äúis the motor moving?‚Äù, along with ‚Äúare we telling it to move with X power or more?‚Äù  If we‚Äôre telling it to move and it isn‚Äôt moving, then after a couple of seconds we tell it to stop.  Pretty simple, and we haven‚Äôt had an issue since!

Code posted here: Precautionary Measures Against Climber Plate Bending - #10 by wlogeais

Current-limiting the motor can also be useful, but can run into issues in a case like climbing, if you expect high-current while in use - it can be hard to differentiate (aka find the limit) between ‚Äúnormal climbing current‚Äù and ‚Äúoops we‚Äôre stalled current‚Äù.

link_counts.title: Precautionary Measures Against Climber Plate Bending

posts.name: Billfred Leverette (he/him/not Bill)
posts.cooked:
Beyond current limiting and ensuring the motors aren‚Äôt being commanded to run so slow it might as well be stall, during the Electric City playoffs (where we were playing hard defense without the current limiting benefits due to some meatball surgery we had to do earlier at the event) we resorted to active cooling between matches.

The classic method for FRC teams was to flip an air duster upside down and use the propellant to cool motors.  Still works, though I would apply it in judicious spritzes to any motor to ensure thermal shock doesn‚Äôt crack something.  (In brushed motors, that was often a brush or magnet.  Not sure what would be the thing that fails on a NEO, but I wasn‚Äôt about to gamble our regional to find out.)

The safer method is airflow‚Äìlots of steady room temperature air.  You could wire up a custom circuit and use robot-legal fans for this (FIRST Choice has some beefy options), but we used a fan similar to this one (it‚Äôs a private-label unit, so different seller but it‚Äôs surely the same fan) pointed at the NEOs and main breaker to get them down around ambient between matches.  We moved one fan back and forth just clipped to a frame member, though we have plans to have at least two available during Championship so we can just throw one on each side.  It charges over either a Micro USB or USB-C cable, so it‚Äôs easy to keep topped up between uses (or to keep it powered externally).

Allen Gregory tipped me off to that fan; during the last year and a half, indoor dining was obviously a little sketchy due to COVID so I‚Äôd frequently eat lunch in the car.  Except I don‚Äôt want to run the A/C and burn gas‚Äìeven Prius amounts of gas.  If I park in shade, drop the windows, and have that fan pointed at me, I can stay cool enough in a South Carolina summer to get through lunch without being a sweaty mess.

If $35-40 for a fan (times two) is too rich for your blood, this $15 AA-powered clip fan is a favorite at work when we modify toys to accept an accessibility switch.  It‚Äôs smaller than the first one and I haven‚Äôt tested it for this application, but it still kicks off a stout amount of air for the money.  (Protip: Rechargeable AAs generally run at 1.2V rather than 1.5 for disposable alkaline cells.  If you value performance over sustainability with these cheap fans, go Rayovac disposables‚Äìwhen I had a business using tons of AAs to power LEGO motors, they consistently offered the best bang for the buck.)

This is more for cooling a drivetrain that is thrashing for the whole match, but hopefully it sparks some thoughts.

posts.name: James Kirby
posts.cooked:
Our 2022 robot had trouble with the shooter NEOs overheating after three minutes of shooting. For us this was down to gearing the drums too high and having to run the motors at low RPM, but we did come up with a good solution. A pair of 6mm thick aluminium plates with a 40mm computer fan basically fixed the problem, bolted in between the motor and HDPE frame. This acted as more of a heatsink than a active cooling solution, but it soaked and held enough heat to keep temps appropriate for a match, then the fans could slowly cool the plate down in between.

posts.name: Gus Michel II
posts.cooked:
NaHick2129:

motors are supposed to cool through the faceplate

This is correct - the coils are on the stator, which is mounted to that faceplate.

How are your NEOs mounted?  To a metal plate, or a plastic one?  If plastic, consider changing to a metal mounting plate, or add a heat sink between the motor and the plastic mounting plate that extends beyond the motor and allows extra cooling surface area.  This heat sink could be made of some rather light (18 ga) aluminum or copper sheet, or even heavy foil.  As noted elsewhere, a fan on whatever your heat sink is would also help.

posts.name: Nathan Hickman
posts.cooked: they are mounted to the face of a custom aluminum gearbox. the part they are mounted to is very thin though and there is a large amount of pocketing on the plate itself the part of the robot they are in also does not allow for very good cooling of the motors. so yes we did kind of shoot ourselves in the foot but we have considered getting rid of the pocketting on the plated that the NEOs are mounted to as well as adding some thermal paste to the faceplate of the motor and adding a current limit. if you can‚Äôt tell we are kind of paranoid of smoking more motors after we smoked so many this season (6 total 4 big ones and 2 550s)
